Providing for Individual Needs

If students need help making the cylinder and the cone, distribute Centimeter Grid Paper so they can more easily make the cylinder and measure the height of the flattened sphere. If the diameters of the other shapes are 6 cm or 8 cm, they can also benefit from one of the nets in Learning Aid 4.2A: Nets of Cones to more quickly fit a cone to the cylinder.

As groups work on the Problem, make sure that the cylinders they make are very close in diameter to their spheres.

If students follow the directions for the experiment carefully, they will find that the flattened sphere occupies about two thirds of the cylinder, indicating that the sphere’s volume is 2/3 of the cylinder’s volume. In this case, there are several ways to formulate the symbolic rule for this relationship. The cone filled with rice or sand fills 1/3 of the cylinder, indicating that the cone’s volume is 1/3 of the cylinder’s volume.

On Day 2 (or when students are ready) distribute Learning Aid 4.2B: Comparing Volumes of Cylinders, Spheres and Cones to be used for What If Situation A.

Planning for the Summary

What evidence will you use in the summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know Question? What will you do if you do not have evidence?

Now What Do You Know?

If a sphere and a cone have the same dimensions as a cylinder, how do the volumes compare? What formulas for the volume of a sphere and the volume of a cone can you write using these relationships?

[As students are conducting the experiment in the Initial Challenge listen for the relationships they are seeing. The cone is 1/3 the volume of the cylinder. The sphere is 2/3 the volume of the cylinder. Volume of a cylinder = r x r x π. Volume of a cone (with the same height) = 1/3(r x r x π). Volume of a sphere (with the same height) = 2/3(r x r x π)]
